answer_html: Firstly this means that the row reduced form of A is the identity matrix (since it has n pivots) so option b is correct and secondly it means that there are no rows of zeros which means that det(A) \(\neq\) 0, so option e is correct.Therefore, from starting with the definition of an inverse we were able to deduce that all of the options are correct.

Firstly this means that the row
reduced form of \emph{A} is the identity matrix (since it has \emph{n}
pivots) so \textbf{option b is correct} and secondly it means that there
are no rows of zeros which means that det(\emph{A}) $\neq$ 0, so
\textbf{option e is correct}.Therefore, from starting with the definition of an inverse we were able
to deduce that \textbf{all} of the options are correct.
hints_html: By isolating one property of an inverse can you use it to deduce other properties that support or eliminate options?
hints_latex:
By isolating one property of an inverse can you use it to deduce other
properties that support or eliminate options?
hints_raw: By isolating one property of an inverse can you use it to deduce other properties that support or eliminate options?
question: A 27
sols_html:
Recall that the definition of an inverse of A denoted A-1 is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}AA^{-1}=A^{-1}A=I\end{aligned}\]

where I is the identity. Now assume we want to solve Ax = 0 for some x. If A is invertible then by the above property we can left multiply by A-1 to get

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}=A^{-1}0=0\end{aligned}\]

so we conclude that if A is invertible then Ax = 0 only has x = 0, the trivial solution and that option c is correct.

Now assume we wanted to find eigenvalues Av’ = ”\(\lambda\)v. If we wanted to find zero eigenvalues then we’d need to solve Av”’ = 0 but as we saw above, the only solution to this if A is invertible is v = 0 which is not a valid eigenvector. Therefore, if A is invertible then it does not have any zero eigenvalues and option d is correct.

A square matrix A of size n \(\times\) n always has n eigenvalues. If the matrix has rank r then there are always r non-zero eigenvalues and n − r zero eigenvalues. Since in this case we have shown that there are no zero eigenvalues then n − r = 0 or n = r, thus the matrix A has rank n and option a is correct.

Recall that rank has to do with the number of pivots in a row reduced matrix. If A has full rank (rank n) then there will be n pivots which means two things. We have shown that all invertible matrices have rank n. Firstly this means that the row reduced form of A is the identity matrix (since it has n pivots) so option b is correct and secondly it means that there are no rows of zeros which means that det(A) \(\neq\) 0, so option e is correct.

Therefore, from starting with the definition of an inverse we were able to deduce that all of the options are correct.
sols_latex:
Recall that the definition of an inverse of \emph{A} denoted
\emph{A}\textsuperscript{-1} is

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle{}AA^{-1}=A^{-1}A=I
\end{align*}

where \emph{I} is the identity. Now assume we want to solve
\emph{A}\textbf{x} = 0 for some \textbf{x}. If \emph{A} is invertible
then by the above property we can left multiply by
\emph{A}\textsuperscript{-1} to get

\begin{align*}
\mathbf{x}=A^{-1}0=0
\end{align*}

so we conclude that if \emph{A} is invertible then \emph{A}\textbf{x} =
0 only has \textbf{x} = 0, the trivial solution and that \textbf{option
c is correct}.

Now assume we wanted to find eigenvalues \emph{A\textbf{\emph{v}' =
''$\lambda$}}v\textbf{. If we wanted to find zero eigenvalues then we'd need to
solve \emph{A}}v''' = 0 but as we saw above, the only solution to this
if \emph{A} is invertible is \textbf{v} = 0 which is not a valid
eigenvector. Therefore, if \emph{A} is invertible then it does not have
any zero eigenvalues and \textbf{option d is correct}.

A square matrix \emph{A} of size \emph{n} $\times$ \emph{n} always has \emph{n}
eigenvalues. If the matrix has rank \emph{r} then there are always
\emph{r} non-zero eigenvalues and \emph{n} − \emph{r} zero eigenvalues.
Since in this case we have shown that there are no zero eigenvalues then
\emph{n} − \emph{r} = 0 or \emph{n} = \emph{r}, thus the matrix \emph{A}
has rank \emph{n} and \textbf{option a is correct}.

Recall that rank has to do with the number of pivots in a row reduced
matrix. If \emph{A} has full rank (rank \emph{n}) then there will be
\emph{n} pivots which means two things. We have shown that all
invertible matrices have rank \emph{n}. Firstly this means that the row
reduced form of \emph{A} is the identity matrix (since it has \emph{n}
pivots) so \textbf{option b is correct} and secondly it means that there
are no rows of zeros which means that det(\emph{A}) $\neq$ 0, so
\textbf{option e is correct}.

Therefore, from starting with the definition of an inverse we were able
to deduce that \textbf{all} of the options are correct.
sols_raw:
Recall that the definition of an inverse of ''A'' denoted ''A''<sup>-1</sup> is

:<math>
\displaystyle{}AA^{-1}=A^{-1}A=I
</math>

where ''I'' is the identity.  Now assume we want to solve ''A'''''x''' = 0 for some '''x'''.  If ''A'' is invertible then by the above property we can left multiply by ''A''<sup>-1</sup> to get

:<math>
\mathbf{x}=A^{-1}0=0
</math>

so we conclude that if ''A'' is invertible then ''A'''''x''' = 0 only has '''x''' = 0, the trivial solution and that '''option c is correct'''.

Now assume we wanted to find eigenvalues ''A'''''v''' = ''&lambda;'''''v'''.  If we wanted to find zero eigenvalues then we'd need to solve ''A'''''v''' = 0 but as we saw above, the only solution to this if ''A'' is invertible is '''v''' = 0 which is not a valid eigenvector.  Therefore, if ''A'' is invertible then it does not have any zero eigenvalues and '''option d is correct'''.

A square matrix ''A'' of size ''n'' &times; ''n'' always has ''n'' eigenvalues.  If the matrix has rank ''r'' then there are always ''r'' non-zero eigenvalues and ''n'' &minus; ''r'' zero eigenvalues.  Since in this case we have shown that there are no zero eigenvalues then ''n'' &minus; ''r'' = 0 or ''n'' = ''r'', thus the matrix ''A'' has rank ''n'' and '''option a is correct'''.

Recall that rank has to do with the number of pivots in a row reduced matrix.  If ''A'' has full rank (rank ''n'') then there will be ''n'' pivots which means two things.  We have shown that all invertible matrices have rank ''n''.  Firstly this means that the row reduced form of ''A'' is the identity matrix (since it has ''n'' pivots) so '''option b is correct''' and secondly it means that there are no rows of zeros which means that det(''A'') &ne; 0, so '''option e is correct'''.

Therefore, from starting with the definition of an inverse we were able to deduce that '''all''' of the options are correct.
statement_html:
Which of the following statements are true for all invertible n \(\times\) n invertible matrices A:

  • (a) A has rank n.

  • (b) The reduced row echelon form of A is the identity matrix.

  • (c) The homogeneous problem Ax = 0 has only the trivial solution x = 0.

  • (d) A does not have \(\lambda\) = 0 as an eigenvalue.

  • (e) det(A) \(\neq\) 0.
statement_latex:
Which of the following statements are true for all invertible \emph{n} $\times$
\emph{n} invertible matrices \emph{A}:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  \textbf{(a)} \emph{A} has rank \emph{n}.
\item
  \textbf{(b)} The reduced row echelon form of \emph{A} is the identity
  matrix.
\item
  \textbf{(c)} The homogeneous problem \emph{A}\textbf{x} = 0 has only
  the trivial solution \textbf{x} = 0.
\item
  \textbf{(d)} \emph{A} does not have \emph{$\lambda$} = 0 as an eigenvalue.
\item
  \textbf{(e)} det(\emph{A}) $\neq$ 0.
\end{itemize}
statement_raw:
Which of the following statements are true for all invertible ''n'' &times; ''n'' invertible matrices ''A'':

* '''(a)''' ''A'' has rank ''n''.
* '''(b)''' The reduced row echelon form of ''A'' is the identity matrix.
* '''(c)''' The homogeneous problem ''A'''''x''' = 0 has only the trivial solution '''x''' = 0.
* '''(d)''' ''A'' does not have ''&lambda;'' = 0  as an eigenvalue.
* '''(e)''' det(''A'') &ne; 0.
